tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
One of David's chief musicians had this same name. This may refer to him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:039:001|39:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"This is a psalm that Asaph wrote." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:053:001|53:1]].
"I prayed with my arms extended"

tn.ref: My soul refused to be comforted
tn.text: The "soul" is a metonym for the person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I would not allow anyone to try to comfort me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I thought of God as I groaned; I thought about him as I grew faint
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"as my spirit grew faint" or "as my spirit was overwhelmed"

This may be a musical term that tells people how to sing or play their instruments here. Some translations write the Hebrew word, and some translations do not include it. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:003:001|3:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_transliterate]])
After speaking about God, Asaph speaks to God in verse 4 and then returns to speaking about God.
"I said to God, 'You held my eyes open.'"
Open eyes is a metonym for being unable to sleep. AT: "kept me from sleeping"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the days of old, about times long past
tn.text: If necessary, "days of old" and "times long past" can be combined. AT: "about things that happened a very long time ago" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This is an idiom for remembering. AT: "I remembered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Another possible meaning is "what was happening."

tn.ref: Will the Lord reject me forever? Will he never again show me favor?
tn.text: These two phrases express feeling rejection from the Lord. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"do things that show that he is pleased with me"
Because Asaph was not sure of the answer to these questions, they are probably literal questions and should be translated literally.

In speaking of Yahweh's "covenant faithfulness" David is trusting that Yahweh will always love him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:013:005|13:5]]. AT: "faithful love" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
**Had God forgotten to be gracious?
These are two expressions stating similar concept of God not showing compassion. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Had his anger shut off his compassion
tn.text: Asaph speaks of anger as if it were a person shutting a door to keep another person, compassion, from coming out, AT: "Had God stopped showing us compassion because he was angry with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Possible meanings are 1) the psalmist was speaking to himself or 2) the psalmist was speaking to Yahweh.

tn.ref: the changing of the right hand of the Most High toward us
tn.text: The "right hand" is a metonym for power,authority or strength. AT: "the Most High no longer uses his power to help us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer begins to speak to Yahweh.
"remember" See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:074:001|74:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"the wonderful things you did long ago"

tn.ref: I will ponder all your deeds and will reflect on them.
tn.text: These two phrases express the concept of meditating on what Yahweh has done. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"think deeply about"
"think of what they mean"
The writer continues to speak to Yahweh.

tn.ref: what god compares to our great God?
tn.text: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "no god compares to our great God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: revealed your strength among the peoples
tn.text: "shown people from many people groups how strong you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: gave your people victory ... the descendants
tn.text: "gave us, your people, victory ... us who are the descendants"
"enabled your people to defeat their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: the descendants of Jacob and Joseph
tn.text: This refers to the entire nation of Israel.

tn.ref: The waters saw you ... they were afraid ... the depths trembled
tn.text: Asaph speaks of the water as if it were a person who saw something that terrified him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: the waters saw you, and they were afraid; the depths trembled
tn.text: "water" and "depth" refers to large bodies of water such as the sea or ocean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"deepest waters"
Asaph speaks of the clouds as if they were people pouring water out of containers. AT: "Much rain fell" or "It rained very hard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This is a metaphor that describes lightning as God's arrows. AT: "the lightning you made flashed like arrows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Use your language's word for what an arrow does after someone shoots it.
This is personification, referring to the thunder as the voice of God. AT: "voice, which was as loud as thunder" or "very loud voice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The lightning seemed to light up the whole world. AT: "lightning lit up everything as far as you could see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
These two phrases have similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Asaph is speaking of Yahweh as if Yahweh was a person with feet. While this is personification, it should be translated literally, if possible. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one saw your footprints" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: You led your people like a flock
tn.text: This simile compares God's people to a flock of animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The phrase "by the hand of" here means "by the action of" or "through the action of."
Here "hand" is synechdoche for the whole person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
